reviews.review_msg: I had been learning a lot about conducting ethical research (e.g., seeking consent from research participants) in his awesome course! I even received a certificate for conducting ethical research on people called the TCPS 2: Core 2022!
He is a nice guy and not a tough grader. He can drive you crazy with his rumbling but if you need a class that you helps to increase  your GPA , stick to him.

Other reviews are correct. He rambles a lot, lectures are unclear, doesnt grade anything, so you wont know if you're doing well or not in the course. randomly assigns work thats not on the syllabus for credit. hes nice enough but poor communicator. only good thing i can think of is if he has to cancel class, he'll make a video lecture.
Only a couple of assignments. TA helped a lot. The prof lectures were confusing sometimes but the canvas posts explained everything pretty well.
Lectures were tedious but the tutorials were fun at times and helpful. All the feedback for the assignments was  super helpful and caring for the other assignments.

Nick's lectures could use some work but the assignments are arranged for you to learn a lot if you pay attention to his feedback, (which is very thorough, more than I have ever had before). He is not an easy marker but if you work hard you will become a better researcher. Good class, I feel like I learned more than I expected.

The other reviews are accurate regarding his lectures. He kinda rambles on and is unclear what he is trying to say. I get lost in his lectures a lot and often find them unhelpful. The good thing is that attendance isn't mandatory so you can skip his classes since attending his class is honestly kinda a waste of time.
he was so unclear and his lectures unhelpful to the assignments

This class was very difficult to keep up with. It was online, but required a lot of collaboration with other students. Weekly modules were frequently late, assignments were unclear. Felt like a lot of busy work for no real benefit. Way more work than a 200-level course should be -- I'm a 4th year and this was my heaviest course this semester.

Very caring and passionate about the material, but lectures are difficult to keep up with. Often wanders a bit and isn't entirely clear about the points he's making. Assignments are a little difficult to understand, but the grading checklists are helpful for figuring out what components need to be in them.
Very passionate, just not good at teaching the content. He is unclear about what he actually wants with most assignments and rubrics/descriptions are very vague. The grading is also very tough.
I agree with the other posts, but really just talk to him. He's a nice guy he'll work with you if you have questions or concerns. super passionate about the subject too which is a plus!

Nick is a very light hearted prof but he doesn't teach well at all. He is very jumpy with his content. I have had one in-class course with him and now one remote-learning class. In both he talks a LOT but never clearly gets to the point. His email responses are very vague and only consist of a few words or one sentence

Despite being passionate about the topics, he lacked the ability to clearly teach the class. His grading was all over the place and the syllabus didn't explain how anything would be marked. And, so much was marked incredibly unfairly without reason -- Avoid this professor!

just terrible. he didn't give criteria for participation and then added it as an assignment after the semester had finished. knocked me down by 20% despite the fact that I had participated extensively during the semester. Just terribly disorganized professor and TA. do NOT enroll with dr. scott unless you're willing to destroy your GPA.

confused, and cuts you off when you ask questions for clarification. Dr. Scott seems like a kind person, but as a professor... Such simple course content was made so much more difficult than need be especially for a first year course. Beware of rubrics! they're not exactly what he's looking for and you won't know what until the end of the semester

Professor Scott is super helpful and caring IF you go during office hours. He almost always allows extensions on reasonable matters which is nice but you're graded on very little assignments and lectures don't discuss how to code.

Lots of assignments. Here's what you need to know: read the criteria like crazy + ask a lot of questions, he doesn't make everything clear + follow the structures of other research works or articles. Read his work He is a nice guy but very laid back and unstructured. Grading will vary and he has harder/higher standards than he seems to have.

I understood course content completely, followed instructions, and received horrifically low grades. Students were being docked marks over page limit confusions and then marks were restored later? Class avg. on assignments were in the 60s and 70s until "reviewed." All students shared the same frustrations, and yet our feedback was ignored.

The class content is quite complex but manageable if you have taken courses about qualitative and quantitative research before, All semester the prof was very unclear on assignment descriptions/grading criteria and loved to talk about his own research (bicycles) a lot.

Dr. Scott's lecture is good, however where he falls short is his assignments. The assignments are worth a lot but it is unclear what is expected, and he is a tough grader. I feel that I have a good grasp on the course content but it is not at all reflected in my grade, the assignments are that hard. Start them early so you can ask him things early.

Nick is a really nice guy & you can tell he wants you to do well, but his lectures are long-winded, often off tangent & his grading criteria isn't very specific. I found his choice of readings long & sometimes dull. He is sometimes difficult to get in contact with but he is an easy marker, doesn't assign many assignments & gives awesome feedback.

Easiest quantitative credit! If you have a difficult time with math then I recommend taking this class because it's a mix of both qualitative and quantitative work. The tutorials helped me a lot. The TA was really nice and easy to talk to. The prof is quite helpful but really disorganized with his assignments and emails.

The professor for this course is not punctual whatsoever. Showed up late almost every lecture, but more importantly handed marked things back really late, posted grades late, and waited to the last day to give back final things, participation and final grades. Replies to emails very late. Very disorganized/flustered, not very professional.

This professor and class is a joke. Super disorganized, late marker, few things that are weighted heavy. Seems easy but marks ridiculously. DO NOT TAKE THIS WITH THIS PROF. Got straight As in all my other 3 classes, this one was far from an A when I worked hard, did what was asked. Prof had a different opinion on my project and graded me very poor

Would have dropped this if I didn't need a quantitative. Hands back assignments really late. TA this semester does not know English and his feedback is not helpful at all if you want to improve. Better to go to the prof directly for help. Tough grader. The prof replied back to my email 1 day before the assignment was due. Take this class if needed

This is the worst class (besides statistics). The lectures and tutorials are such a bore, the marking is really tough, only talks about and focuses on what the prof is interested in, unorganized, 2 big assignments at the start of the semester. Such a waste of my time. Not impressed, if it wasnt mandatory Id drop right away. Learned nothing.

So far this class is going pretty well. Prof makes his syllabus throughout the semester. Nicholas is very passionate and understanding. The TA this semester is really useless and not that helpful. Tutorials are pointless unless you have Nicholas as the one giving lecture in tutorial. The assignments are pretty straightforward but a lot of work.

The prof is young and laidback. Tough marker! Does not reply to emails on time. Gives back assignments really late. Very unorganized, the TA this semester does not seem to be too familiar with the Canadian education system so hopefully that does not affect my grade.

Laid back prof with a big heart for helping students succeed. If you're having difficulty with the material, talk to him immediately. Projects are flexible. Don't be afraid to be bold with your ideas.

Nick is super high-energy and really loves what he teaches. Unfortunately he is sometimes tactless and doesn't think before he speaks. If you make an effort to speak up in class and offer your ideas he will love you. Beware: he talks about his research a LOT and he makes up assignment guidelines as he goes. However, I learned a lot in his course.

Professor Scott is really engaging and passionate about this course, it shows in his lectures. I can see why people think SA255 is hard because it requires for individualized thinking. Overall great structure and prof for a mandatory Sociology major course. Attend classes and get a higher mark!

It's the basics of social research, not a terribly exciting topic, so it might be a bit unfair to blame the prof for the class not being very interesting. Lots of busy work in class. Expectations are clear for each of the writing assignments. This isn't a hard class or a hard prof. If you're struggling, make time to talk to him.

Nicholas is kind and passionate about his work but is very vague on what he wants for his assignments. His TA was the worst, she would show up late and often would not be engaged in the lecture. He doesn't take attendance during tutorials so I'm not sure how he based our participation marks on.

Nice person and is clearly passionate but what he is teaching. BUT it is clearly is own self interests that he is teaching and not teaching the student learn foundations of social research. Assignments are extremely vague and only shows examples what he want for assignments from student work AFTER THE ASSIGNMENT IS DUE!

Nick's an engaging prof. Made lecture and tutorials engaging with different activities. It is a very hands on learning environment, which I enjoyed. (but takes lots of time) The one thing I found challenging was how vague the assignments were. However, he does give lots of good and helpful feedback.
This was my favourite class at SFU!

Nick is a nice teacher however he is not the best professor. He tends to fall off track often. The assignments we have to do are ridiculous. No one understands what we are supposed to do/ achieve. He is very vague about his expectations and does not clearly explain any concepts

Nick is  clearly passionate about what he's teaching. However, his approach to this course is what I would expect from an advanced 3 or 400 level applied research methods course. The way he teaches this course is not appropriate for the level most students are at and does not allow students to establish a solid knowledge base for research methods.
Assignments are vague and confusing
I enjoyed the way he teaches because it was more hands on and therefore I felt I got a better understanding of the concepts. His instructions aren't clear.

You're forced to go and do fieldwork in some random place in Vancouver- really don't have time for that. On my days off, I am not interested in going somewhere that takes a relatively long time to get to, especially when it's raining to do work (which the prof does not provide much guidance on). He is passionate about what he teaches though.

As a fairly new professor, his marking is hard. Considering 70% of your overall grade are from assignments, he does not provide very detailed instructions as they aren't very organized and are not very clear; they are very broad and vague. He expects your analysis to be just as strong as his, and if not, it will show in the low mark he gives you.
Kinda more into his own stuff than into teaching. Really likes Vancouver neighbourhoods.
Awesome!

Thought this class was  an intro to social research but it ended up being about Vancouver neighborhoods, sustainability and mobility. He seemed to expect the class to understand these concepts without teaching the foundations and research methods. Assignment heavy with little criteria and notice. Replies to emails take a long time.

SA255 was a waste of time. Poorly organized: did not upload slides after saying he would and being asked repeatedelywould upload project details 10 days before due date vague assingment details. Irrelevant lectures that dont relate to assingments.  Emphasis on mobile methods and city neighbourhoods yet this is a Quatitative course.  DO NOT TAKE!!

Came into this class thinking I would be learning about research methods. Instead I feel like I took a class on Vancouver Neighborhoods as the main topic. I don't understand the central point of what he is trying to teach & he doesn't always reply back for emails. So confused. Feels like i need backgroud knowledge on Vancouver neighborhoods
His classes are confusing. Jumps from one topic to another not explaining either one correctly.
